column4: I found via google that I can use "sudo mount -t vfat /dev/sda1 /mnt/usb" to mount my usb flash drive, however this gives me read-only access.  Is there a way I can mount it so that users can modify the content of the flash drive.
an easy way would be to put an entry in fstab. sudo nano -w /etc/fstab
It's one of those key-fob things, it isn't always in.
then you can just do mount /mnt/usb as a user
just add that line to fstab
you might also consider using auto as the file system type, just incase it's not going to be fat
Okay, I added that to fstab.  Does that mean it'll magically mount when I plug it in now or I gotta issue a command?
usually you have to mount it manually, but try it anyway
gnome might automatically mount it for you
even if you have to mount it, it's as easy as doing: mount /mnt/usb
do I need to do unmount /mnt/usb or will it take care of that when I pull it?
it should unmount it for you
